There a lots of blueprints and crafts I never touched even after I 100% the game. I might be interested in the decorations system if there was a way that it impacted gameplay but it just feels like clutter to me. I would say the first game is more concise experience where this game try's some new things that don't fit into the bigger picture.

I agree with another reviewer here who said that not adding new, more interesting (gameplay-wise) slimes - and instead sticking with 80% of the ones from SR1 - wasn't the best choice. On one hand, it doesn't add that much new content for those of us who've played the first game, but on the other hand it feels like there's a stronger connection to the prequel, and it makes it feel familiar (instead of throwing you in a completely new environment -- which wouldn't be a problem, really, if they still keep the same mechanics). That and the conservatory being hell to walk through and not having anything interesting past the decorations to make it your own

But yeah, other than that, it's just a fun game. One thing I see with some "relaxing"/"farming" games is that they lack action, which most players are still looking for (because after all, it's not fun to just sit around and do the same monotonous thing over and over again without a goal). And SR2 managed to add some really interesting gameplay parts (for lack of a better term), that don't make you feel like you're rushing to beat The Boss(!!!) or that there's a ticking time bomb that is going to end the whole universe once it goes off. The grind for materials is real, though

I also wanna add that I really, really like the aesthetic of this game. It feels... sparkly? -- without it being too much. It's fantasy and yet oddly familiar. And compared to the environment of SR1 (referring mostly to the base), SR2 feels so much more lively with all the greenery. And the conservatory itself feels very cozy, and being practically huge, it doesn't make you feel like you're "trapped" inside

Overall, nice game. You can see clearly just how much I've enjoyed it myself

I played this game when early access first released back in 2022 (on xbox). Honestly, the difference from playing early access on day 1 to release doesn't feel like much. For major areas, they added the gray labyrinth and powderfall bluffs (two areas in three years). If you asked me what they were doing for three years, I wouldn't be able to give you a proper answer. Development over those few years was rather slow, and I feel bad for anyone who had to wait ages for any updates. I'm aware that they're a smaller studio, but months between updates? There's smaller studios that put out less updates more frequently.

Gathering slimes is slightly different as opposed to the first game (for some species). In the first game, you just run around and grab up the slimes whenever you want. But in this game, specific slimes will only happen at certain times / weather events. Take the tangle slime for example. For slime rancher 1, you'd just run to the glass desert and grab a few. Now? You need to wait for a pollen event. Not just any pollen event, a level three pollen event. There's 3 possible levels, and they happen at random times (level 3 being rather rare). It took me ~80 days to get my first level 3 pollen event without sleeping a bunch to skip days. Super unlucky, but slimes shouldn't be based on an rng system like that. Tangle and dervish are currently the only slimes that spawn in rare weather events. 

Some resources are extremely rare and hard to find, the hardest in my experience being sun sap. It only spawns on specific trees in two areas in the game. Unfortunately, this resource is used in quite a few upgrades and a few decorations, so have fun hunting for it.

Though I have my complaints, the game is still fun. It's definitely a lot grindier compared to the first game. There's no more drills/pumps where you have to wait for your resources. Instead, you go out and find them yourself - or make a drone do it for you passively. If you dislike grindy games, this is not the game for you. In the gray labyrinth, you need almost 800 plorts to open every plort door, and the slimes you get them from are similar to quicksilver slimes from the first game. The slimes are abundant, but the plorts are still annoying to gather. I don't expect this game to get many more updates (considering how long it takes for them to do smaller updates). 

Another thing, the storyline of this game is extremely forgettable. You're dropped off on a new island by a mysterious boat, there's a new character... and it really just wasn't memorable. Personally, slime rancher was never about the plot for me, so this didn't exactly bother me. Wouldn't suggest this game for the storyline at all, just skip the dialog.

But, at its current state, it's a fine game. I'd suggest grabbing it on sale. For me, I'd say it's a solid 8/10 game due to the graphics, gameplay, and music. It's fine if you ignore the time it took to update the game in early access (don't expect frequent updates either).

I gave a pretty glowing review of the original Slime Rancher and since Slime Rancher 2 is just Slime Rancher but better there are no prizes for guessing how this review is going to go. 

Its great. Plain and simple. Adorably, Cozily, Visually spectacular. 

Now why do I like it you might ask? Well there's 5 things in particular I liked. All of these are just straight copied from the first game because hey - it was good then and its still good now. The added stuff? Its all visual, or extra content, or just little automation benefits - all of which is great to have but great is still great even if you add extra. 

1) Its fun to make a farm and get money. Its been fun for ages actually, oddly enough. Ever since Harvest Moon, and then to Rune factory, I've liked the whole farming/economy simulator type games. Were they a bit repetitive? Yup. Did they manage to let me unwind and work at regular challenges and tasks? Yes, and as odd as it sounds its quite fun.

2) The game is adorable. They have a cat slime. That you can mutate with several other genus (?) of slimes. That also somehow makes them larger. Why is that? Because its adorable, that's why. And the cat slime isn't even the cutest one.

3) You get a vacuum cleaner gun. Color me biased, its fun to use and I flipping loved Luigi's Mansion.

4) Upgrades feel meaningful. Early on, your pretty strapped for cash. Get some money? Neato, time to upgrade that pen with a Solar shield so the little glows don't disintegrate at daybreak (like vampires). Got some flyers? They can fly, ya'll need a higher wall. Got a solar shielded, giant walled corral? They are hungry, grow them some food. And so on. Money is not impossible to come by (far from it), and makes life a lot easier for you in noticeable bounds with every penny you pour back into your farm. Higher walls offer more containment, fertile soil grows plants faster, silo upgrades give you more space. Also almost every upgrade has a aesthetic associated with it. That's quality right there.

5) Its a game that just wants to be a game. Honestly its a real problem nowadays with economic styled games - they force you to suffer until you can get better off. And I don't mind that, in fact I enjoy that in Rune Factory and Harvest Moon. Working to get your feet off the ground and be successful with less work isn't just fun, its actually basically the most human desire I can think of in gaming (besides sex). And this game is hard at the beginning to get off the ground. But getting off the ground is fun, and its not ever a grind to do it. Jetpack? Buy it in 1 day, easily. Ranch upgrades? Each one might be expensive, but the essentials are incredibly easy to get. The game lets you have fun with it, and it feels like a real game the entire time.

In many ways, it's both just more of the same game, but also an upgrade. 

It's the same in the sense that the general casual core loop from the first game is still present, and that's good considering that's what a lot of people found endearing about the first game.

It's an upgrade in the sense that they took the ideas they had from the first game and iterated over it, allowing certain mechanics to be integrated more fluidly with the rest of the game. One of my main issues with the first game was slime science. Compared to every core mechanic, it was introduced to the player relatively late and it always felt kind of tedious. This was such a shame considering that some of the best quality of life improvements were stuck behind the system, such as warp portals or the bee drone automations. In here, the mechanic of obtaining materials is much more integral, not just for accessing said quality of life upgrades, but as well as just base upgrades be tied to it. The way materials are implemented in the game provides another reason for exploration and helps distinguish each area in the game; You're not just exploring for the sake of progress or finding a new slime, you're also looking for the best spots to get certain materials. 

The game also gives the player more reason to reexplore areas. What felt lacking about the first game is that each area always felt like a one and done: you go in, explore, get the new slimes, get the new food for each slime, maybe come back for secrets, and rinse and repeat for each area. Here, the weather effects, the caves and passageways that loop back round and create shortcuts, as well as some materials being more abundant in some areas give more variety for the gameplay.

One thing that did feel kind of lacking were the story. At first, I felt intrigued at the mystery and how the characters were connected to the story. However, after a certain part of the game, they all get swept under the rug and relegated as random decoration fabricators all in favor to have all of the story and intrigue be pumped into one character who exposition dumps. I know it's not mandatory to read them, but I felt there was missed potential in having more environmental story telling or maybe even cutscenes. Show, don't tell is all I'm saying. Also, snooping around areas and finding the one treasure you didn't find would have felt more rewarding half of the time if they didn't give me a bush or a tree or something. It didn't help that some of the treasure pods DID have useful stuff in them such as materials for upgrades, since that just meant you HAD to look for the one treasure pod you didn't find only to get a tree.

Overall, I enjoyed my time with the game and if you enjoyed the first game you'll probably enjoy this too

Nearly exactly the same as last game, different slimes (sometimes), less interesting story, and no extractors. I was setting out to gather my next slime pair, favoured veggie to grow knowing I'd be back quickly since I only had four inventory slots only to realise.... I've been here before. many many times.
The lack of ambition, innovation or change in this game is bloody astounding to the point where many things are just "changed" a bit rather than improved. I'm actually impressed they basically "remade" the initial game almost beat for beat and put it out there as a sequel. 

But I'm ranting so here's a list of things better or worse than the last one:
Slimes: half of them return and the are a few new ones. Surprisingly pretty much none of them are interesting. You get a bunny skinned slime, a bat slime, flying butterfly slime, angler fish slimes but compared to the dervish or tangle slimes these feel just like basic skins.
Resource gathering: You have to gather resources from points that respawn rather than put down extractors. This is a huge downgrade and you'll find yourself marking resource points to go on gathering runs in order to build what you need.
Upgrades: being able to buy progressively more expensive stuff in SR1 was dope and gave you a sense of progression as well as somehwere to throw your coins. In sr2 there's no equivilent. You buy individual decorations and thats it. Your ranch feels "Finished" from the get go.
Expansion: Exactly...EXACTLY the same as previous. North, West, East, each upgrade gives you five more plots, walking between them is annoying and pointless but probably there to limit slimes in one area and lag. Just wildly unimaginative. 
Plots themselves - exactly the same as previous
Drones - Unlocked way to late in the game to matter. Expect to do a lot of micromanagement, even more so than the last game since you have resource collection now. You also have to find 18 drone parts hidden around which admittedly is kind of cool but it also limits you to 18 drones if you grind, and yeah.... the micro management is a feature not a bug. 
Inventory - My F'ing god 4 slots, with potential to upgrade to 6 much later on. WHY? Expect a hell of a lot of running back and forth between your base to drop off slimes, resources, and food. But I guess that's the point, there's so little to do they need to pad the game out by adding much more running back and forth.
Levels - Umm.. they're much more colourful? Lots of bright pastels enough to make me vomit from my eyes after awhile. Nothing so much as interesting as the ruins with the quantum slimes or the glass desert or even the wilds. 
Gordo's - Still annoying and you'll be running back and forth with your limited inventory space to get them food

And so on. After awhile I realised the loop just wasn't fun anymore. 

Conclusion - Monomi Park really hit a fantastic loop but then decided to milk it to death. While the first game ended at just the right point, playing the second just feels like it you kept on playing right after the end of the first one. Reflecting on the experience I can't even think of one thing it does to improve on or introduce as an exciting change to the formula. How about new pen types? no. Slimes with interesting mechanics? no. Increased inventory space so you're not running back and forth collecting two-three things at a time or mule-ling food to Gordos? no. 

Play the game if you really want to scratch that itch, but otherwise a really pointless and dissapointing sequel. 


Edit - Just wanted to add one thing, the music is genuinely amazing.

Everything I liked from SR1 is here, but overdone to the point where there's more bloat than game. SR1 had a very simple and effective gameplay loop: find slimes, ranch slimes, earn money, buy better tools and more space to ranch slimes more effectively, repeat. The story was very simple: a rancher has come to the ranch to ranch slimes. Simple but effective, literally all you need.

The maps in SR2 are bigger and extremely beautiful, but you'll get sick of them very quickly, because a lot of this game is sprinting back and forth, and after a while it becomes clear that these pretty maps are just there to add distance to your many, many sprints. You can't just use your earnings to buy upgrades for your tools anymore, you need special items to create them. These items are hidden on these huge, multilayered maps, with zero hints as to where they are. Along with cosmetics.

I think about 75% of all hidden treasures are cosmetics. If you care about those, cool, you'll have a better time than I did. I do not care about cosmetics, and having tool upgrades mixed in among them had me reaching for a guide almost immediately. Looking for an upgrade part and finding nothing but flower pots and rocks is very discouraging. This becomes especially frustrating in the endgame, where you need a rare resource to even open a treasure that may have the upgrade part you desperately need, or a blueprint for a flower pot. No way to tell until you've grinded out those resources.

There's a LOT of grind throughout the game. Everything that's worth building requires a lot of materials, and those materials can only be acquired by running around those huge maps and hoping you spot a handful of them in a very visually busy environment. Eventually you'll get access to gathering drones, but sure enough, those also require a ton of resources and hidden parts to build.

The story is no longer about a rancher who wants to make money on a ranch. It now includes time travel, chosen ones, galactic disturbances, a quest to save the world in the future I think... It's very overdone and nowhere near as touching as the extremely simple story of SR1. There's a comm station where you get calls from your friends. They call every five minutes. They give you more cosmetics.

The only thing I haven't mentioned yet is the ranching, but don't worry. You won't do much of it.

SR2 is SR1 but every aspect of it is bloated to bursting. If, like me, you just wanted more of the same, you'll get it. You just have to take on all these frustrations along with it. I did have fun with it in places, I did finish it, and I wish I could give it something better than a thumbs down. But this is SR1 with all the effective elements replaced with blueprints for doilies.

God, I would never suspected that Slime Rancher 2 will frustrate me so much, to the point of uninstalling the game. If you want something cozy and wholesome like the first game of this series you'll gonna be dissapointed. It's not like this game is utter garbage - there are plenty of good changes and new stuff, but it can't fix all the new problems that Slime Rancher 2 provides.

For a plus side - the game looks beautiful, has dynamic weather, has more advanced physics (e.g.: many objects react to weather change) and the music is as good as in previous title, even if for me has kinda somber tone. New slimes in most cases looks awesome and some of them have funny new gimmicks like Ringtail Slime that transforms into stone statue under sunlight. New biomes also looks cool and very distinct from one another. Some QOL features (upgrades) are absolutely great like additional slots or the fact that you can carry more of the same stuff. I like the motive of Rainbow Island being this weird color-changing isle (mostly 'cos NPC's refers to that phenomen like if it was some lovecraftian shit).

So what's the problem? Well... There are many of them. First of all. Slime Rancher 2 is for some reason super grindy if you want to upgrade all of your stuff, unlock new stash and new paths in later phase of the game. The amount of some resources and plorts neccesary to do that is astronomical. Would be cool if you can just farm them... But you can't. [spoiler] Shadow Slimes are uncatchable - they work in the same way as Gold Slimes [/spoiler] - and resources spawn in semi-random pattern across biomes. There are no drills or pumps like in the first Slime Rancher so I hope you are patient 'cos you'll be running across all map to collect them.

New world map looks cool and all but is huge without any point for that - most of the locations you'll visit only once for a collectible. It also makes walking unnecessary long so better invest quickly in some teleports. This is also a good place to mention that collectbles that were I would say mostly optional in previous game from this series here are nearly mandatory if you want to craft every upgrade.

The story is plain as hell - you'll meet NPC's from previous game, but for a time they'll just do an exposition dumps and after that they'll constantly nagging you with mostly garbage presents (decorations). [spoiler] The new person that you will meet - for me at least - is boring. I didn't even finish the game and I have a feeling that she is probably a time traveller that somehow contributes to the whole mess of prismatic colors etc. [/spoiler] The new plot is dragged out to the point of it being so obvious that you don't have to finish the game to get the idea of what's going on.

I know that in first Slime Rancher if you sell the same type of plort constantly it loses a value over time. It's the same in this game but somehow worse. Slime Rancher 2 actively punishes you for having an optimal farming strategy. In my save I have only Largos and they produce a ton of plorts. The game economy crashes so much that it takes literally 10 game days of not selling anything to raise the value of every plort to more than +-10 gold. 

But the absolute best/worst thing in this game that break the camel's back is the fact that 3 of the Slimes are locked behind RNG. You can obtain Yolky Slime at random (they just sometimes spawn without any rhyme or reason) and Tangle and Dervish Slimes are locked behind specific weather condition. It wouldn't be that bad if that weather guarantees you these Slimes. But I don't know who though that it would be a great idea - as Tangle Slimes in my save appear always when pollen hits cat 3 - it's not the same for Dervish Slimes. Not only you need to have cat 3 wind (with cyclones) for them to occur - the fact that they will occur at all during this weather is also random... So you have RNG within RNG... Fucking great. I had cat 3 wind with cyclones like maybe 3 or 4 times during my +30h of playing this game and during them I met Dervish Slimes a whole of ZERO times!

But there are snares in the game - you scream at the monitor - and I say yes. I used them... All of them... I started with basic and advanced one and have no luck for 20 game days straight. After that I've got so fed up that I finally found and catched [spoiler] Hyper Slime [/spoiler] to built the master one. But alas... Even the Master Gordo Snare that according to the descripion GUARANTEES the Gordo that you want if you provide their favourite food (Yeah... Guarantees my ass...) didn't give it. I provide Prickle Pear... And I've got a FUCKING PINK GORDO. WTF? After trying to catch this motherfuckers 'cos big "?" mark across Plort Market screen bothers me so much I still didn't get a single Dervish Slime. The problem with catching Dervish Slime was known since Early Access.

After that I just uninstalled this game 'cos it frustrates me so much. Seriously - if you want a cozy game with cute slimes and great story buy the first Slime Rancher. Because Slime Rancher 2 has bland story that is long for sake of it and wants you to constantly grind for resources, locks some of the Slimes behind RNG wall and make some of the previous game features that were optional mandatory.
I have only one question to the developers of this game - who hurt you?

[h1] In short, I feel like the game does not respect the players time. [/h1]

Going back and forth to your farm to pick up plort to open a door is annoying, but it's even more annoying to discover that there was another door that needs a different plort behind the first door and now I need to travel back to the farm to get that one. Everything that helps you move faster like teleporters and drones are grindy to get and don't show up till much later. Managing the ranch became annoying more than it became like something I enjoyed doing.

While I did quite enjoy my playing experience overall, there are quite a few issues or as I'd like to clarify one main issue. The addition of weather events was for example quite fun.
The game is quite fun at times and exploration of the pretty expansive map does give one a sense of acomplishement. It has gotten quite the graphic update since Slime Rancher 1. There are a few new and interessting slime varieties(My personal favorite being the yolky slime). The cosmetics are also pretty cool and the story feels in depth enough, interesting and engaging. But this is sadly where this game seems to kind of missunderstand something. I didnt play Slime Rancher to endlessly farm for Ressources. That should never ever be a given in a game. 
It feels like this aspect of the game is designed to keep players in the game, but with really no other purpose. It feels like an absolute disrespect of my time. Having to scoure the map for ressources for more hours than I would like to admit just to get one goddamn teleporter is an absolute pain in the ass. AND do not get me started on the quantum drones that were released as a feature for the full release. While they are nice and I've been anticipating them since I bought the early acess version. I sadly yet again had to realise that this game does not value the players time at all. The ressources needed to craft even somewhat basic things(such as rare diamonds specifically and a whole lot of other ressources to be compleatly frank) are a pain to farm. In additon to that if you wish to fabricate just about everything you can, good luck to you: expect to spend a whole lot of time just mindlessly running around the entire goddamn map just to find some rare diamonds or other ressources. Because and I wish to emphasise: this game does not value the players time. Once you compleated the story there is nothing else to do. No real other goal. I thought that maybe I could idk unlock another farm or something, the way you could in what i would describe the end or post-end game of Slime Rancher 1. But it seems that even that was not done. Even while the game was in early acess I have struggeled to find anything to do that didnt feel like a mindless waste of my time and energy for little to no payoff. 
It seems that after you compleated the game there is literally only one thing left to do: decorate your farm apperently. Just wow. What great content. 
In the original you at least had to the objective of farming money to buy some upgrades for the ranch. While those were, as far as I can remember, cosmetic for the most part, at least they didnt require you to spend a disrespectful amount of time and energy just mindlessly running around the map trying to find some damn rare ressources. What an absolute pity. I had high hopes, but instead I got left with a feeling of just having wasted quite a bit of my time for nothing. While the story was nice and I did enjoy quite a bit of the game the continues wasting of the players time is absolutely unacceptable and quite frankly just incredibly disrespectful. 
Just to emphasise my point of time wasting:
-A lot, and really do mean a lot, of the recepies need strange diamonds. Strange diamonds are spawned at pretty random locations on the map, they do not have a distinct sound from normal ore that can spawn. So have fun running around the map trying to find a ton of them if you wish to fabricate most things.
-A lot of recepies need gold plorts. While those are somewhat randomly spawned and aquired, these at least can be farmed a little more efficiently after upgrading the vacpack. 
-You need to farm so many shadow plorts and due to them loving to jump into the void that gets really annoying real fast. Yes, i am aware you can corner them in certain spots of the map, that doesnt make this a great feature regardless. 
-You need quite a lot of prisma plots, which if you've ever wanted to feel pure stress in a game, try farming that stuff. I cannot even begin to imagine how much time i spent farming that.
-The general ressource farming has been changed conceptually from the previous game: sadly not in a good way. Everything is now made to spawn more or less randomly...While there are set areas where certain ressources can spawn, you again have to walk around the entirety of those areas to find enough ressources to just fabricate one or two things. That's fun, isnt it? Don't you just love running around aimlessly, just hoping for some luck with spawns, and then of course, rinse and repeat until you begin to wonder why the hell you are even playing this game to begin with. Is it to relax and have some fun? Nope, apperenlty you just love wasting time, now dont you? Or at least that seems to have been what the developers thought, or should i rather say lack of thought perhaps, has led to such a sour experience. Again: Slime Rancher 1 got this right, you had to place your extractors, let them do their things and then come back to get the ressources. That is an acceptable level of grind and doesnt seem that the developers wish to keep you in the game for reasons that arent just keeping you in the game for the sake of honestly what? Just why?
-There are so many recepies (upgrades included) and they all need a ton of ressources if you wish to craft them all. Here you can go to my previous points to find out why that is annoying.
-A lot of recepies call for strange diamonds for what i thing is the same reason I've already mentioned to a point where even I am getting sick of saying it: wasting time to keep you in the game.

TLDR: It has some cool concepts, but massivly disrespects the players time and seems to wish to keep the player playing, not for some cool goal or achivement: nope, just for the sake of wasting time it seems. The original had already struck a good balance, where this game decided to kick it just for the sake of it. The end game content is honestly non existent. What an absolute shame. Try it if you wish, but when a game does not respect your time, you have to.

My kids and I love Slime Rancher to pieces, and I did not hesitate to buy into Slime Rancher 2 on (or close to) day one of its Early Access release on Steam. I have had concerns with the game throughout the development process, but held my tongue until I got to immerse myself fully in the "finished" product.

Steam's question for these reviews is, "Do you recommend this game?" As of the date of my review, my answer is no.

The short version: Slime Rancher (1) is a substantially better game that provides more fun in a more logical gameplay loop, at a much better price. Indeed, Slime Rancher (1) is worth the full list price today. As long as you can buy/play Slime Rancher (1), there is simply not a compelling reason to buy Slime Rancher 2. 

[b][u]Now for the (very) long version, which is FULL of spoilers:[/b][/u]

Slime Rancher 2 is not a bad game, but it is a marked downgrade from the original Slime Rancher in terms of gameplay and the fun factor. This still surprised me because Monami Park clearly poured so many resources into the graphics and level design. It would be a step up if they had simply left the actual gameplay alone.

Instead, they wholeheartedly downgraded the Slime Rancher experience.

The core problem is with how this game conceptualizes resources versus how Slime Rancher--and, frankly, most farming sims/animal-raising games--conceptualizes them.

In Slime Rancher, your primary resource is Plorts (slime poop, basically). You get Plorts by feeding your slimes. Plorts make you money, and money buys you early- and mid-game upgrades. In the late game, you are tasked with finding additional resources in order to fund more advanced upgrades. This process is largely automated and does not substantially interfere with the core, fun part of the game: catch slimes, raise slimes, profit.

In Slime Rancher 2, your Plorts are a minor resource at best. Instead, the game locks even the most basic early-game upgrades behind a resource "paywall." You cannot even get the Jetpack or Dash Boots without hunting and pecking for a relatively large number of extraneous resources, some of which are not even available in the first area. 

In SR2, collecting these special resources is a fully manual process. You have to find the resources in the wild, where they are placed largely at random, and you have to extract them manually (assuming they don't just fall into the ocean or into lava before you can). Since these resources eat up your Vac Pack slots, that's space you cannot use to capture slimes or collect their food. And since you cannot even reach most areas of the game without the early-game gadgets, this means your ability to grow your ranch depends on how much time you spend grinding away hunting and pecking for these resources.

This problem gets worse and worse as the game goes on, and nowhere is it worse than the game's approach to automation. In SR1, at a certain point, you can build drones to automate tasks so that your slimes are well taken-care of while you explore distant lands and complete higher-end challenges. 

In SR2, not only is your ability to automate your ranch locked behind the "resource paywall," but drones also require a specific resource that only appears completely at random, the Strange Diamond. Other key late-game gadgets require Strange Diamonds, including gadgets necessary even to access the game's big "feature area," the Grey Labyrinth. I have gone as long as ten hours in my playthrough without seeing a single Strange Diamond. 

You can see that I have about 81 total hours in the game as I write this review, and I have been able to build exactly ONE drone, for a ranch with a dozen different slime habitats across five game areas. 

Which leads me to the coup de grace, the Grey Labyrinth. Progressing in the Grey Labyrinth requires you to spend A LOT of time there just waiting for certain slimes to appear and random events to occur. But without sufficient access to automation, you cannot spend much time away from your ranch before your slimes get hungry, your chickens overrun the whole place, your food rots, and chaos generally ensues. 

I do hope the folks from Monami Park see reviews like mine and take it as constructive criticism. I hope it gives them an impetus to improve the game post-release and, if there is a Slime Rancher 3, to focus on what got them all the good will from us Slime Rancher fans in the first place: the slimes. But I am not optimistic since everything I have said here echoes feedback players gave Monami Park throughout Early Access and it seems they not only did not listen, but tripled-down on the neverending resource hunt.

[h1]Desperately needs a quality of life update[/h1]

TL;DR: No drones or automation and walking literally anywhere takes between 15 and 30 minutes to get almost no progression. This doesn't feel like Slime Rancher 2; it feels like an alternate reality Slime Rancher 1 where quality of life features are replaced with different slimes.

Slime Rancher 2 puts all its focus into rewarding exploration. This is great in theory, but the execution is...unforgivably repetitive. Around the five hour mark I stretched in my chair and looked around my ranch, and it dawned on me that despite having been very busy for the last several hours, I hadn't accomplished [b]or explored[/b] much of anything because the game demands you run back and forth between areas you've already explored for hours to gather resources you already have hundreds of...

...With no automation, an infuriatingly small inventory, and a plort market that is, much like Slime Rancher 1, always trending down. I am told Drones are in the game, but they come way too late to solve the core issue of highly repetitive gameplay: Harvest crops one at a time. Feed slimes one at a time. Harvest plorts one at a time. Sell plorts one at a time. Then go back and do it again because your inventory is too small to hold a full stack.

I can not stress this enough-- you will meet milestones (unlocking an upgrade, getting a new structure on your ranch, etc) on average every 45 minutes [i]if[/i] you put all your focus into repetitive tasks to grind out resources.

The new slime types look really cool. If all you care about is different slime species, you will probably like Slime Rancher 2. The new slimes are everything I wanted from a Slime Rancher 1 DLC. Also, base decoration has been significantly improved from Slime Rancher 1. 

The maps are colorful, if frustrating to navigate. Their layouts...kind of blur together? I find myself getting turned around in them because the terrain doesn't have enough landmarks, and the color palette makes everything, how do you say, "not look like a landscape" and it messes with how my brain processes the 3D space. It's kind of like being put in a maze where the walls are the color of the floor and vice versa. All the areas also kind of look similar. In Slime Rancher 1, different zones had distinct visual styles, but because SR2 is going for the pastel vibe, most of the areas I've seen so far (that aren't literally on fire) look homogeneous.

This game NEEDS [b]two-way[/b] teleporters and drones in the first two hours. Period. I can't in good faith recommend SR2 until it gets a major quality of life update, because no matter how cool the new slimes are, the game around it doesn't respect your time.
